job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse (LPN) in Potsdam, NY

Not an even work flow ratio if you are good you get more work why the lazy coworker across from you can play on their phone all day, do school work, chat with other coworkers etc.

job_title: Collections and Denials Management Representative in Potsdam, NY
pros: Lots of overtime is granted if you know how to do your job correctly. If you are self motivated there is lots of room for educational growth and you can obtain additional certifications not required for your job if wanted.
cons: Management plays favorites and will allow for poor work ethic among favorites and everyone else has to pick up the slack. Management changes course several times a week or even per day sometimes and micromanage, and even bullies employees at times to scare people into getting more work done.

review_title: Poor management that doesn't care for its staff.
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Potsdam, NY
pros: Hospital is financially stable (for now).  Good outpatient facilities.
cons: Senior Leadership is not capable of sustaining the hospital needs especially considering the rate at which they are trying to grow.  Leaders do not have the ability to care for staff.  Leadership does not properly engage staff and is not responsive to the needs of the staff.  They do not listen and push staff to the limits in every department in the facility.  This is predominantly because proper leadership is not recruited instead any warm body can take a chair and become a VP or supervisor of something.  The hospital is expanding far too fast for the current leadership to manage.  All leaders blame the stress and tension staff feel on the evolution of healthcare.  This is nothing more than an attempt to deflect their own shortcomings and pass the blame. Collapse is inevitable.  The IT department at CPH is the best example.  Leadership in IT is deceitful and has zero concern for its staff.  Half the IT staff has left in the past 2 months.

pros: Nurses work together usually pretty well, patients seemed pretty well taken care of, nurses acted as advocates.
cons: The collaboration nurse to doctor just wasn't there with many of them. Didn't offer tuition help to further education, pay is far lower than other areas... so I left. I don't know what they've done recently. I ACTUALLY had a doctor THROW a chart at me once. NO respect for ancillary staff FYI!! just as a warning!

pros: Excellent growth opportunities, a lot of smiling faces, successful company. Tools and systems are well kept and maintained. Management is actually trying to be better every year. Supporting community needs and helping people.
cons: Too often we see decisions made with not enough planning, and many changes appear to be done hastily with unnecessary urgency. Very high tempo, which sometimes does not leave enough room for excellence.

pros: Outside of IT, many of the director level leaders are good to work for and are experienced in their field. The employees are very friendly and the best people to work with.
cons: The VP level managers are dysfunctional and cannot work together to save their lives. The CIO In particular is insecure, oppressive to his staff and takes credit for his people's work. Don't excel at your profession. You will be shut down!

pros: Financial stability. Pay is okay for the area.
cons: There's this common theme in the nursing profession, and if dates far back into history. Nurses have always been expected to go above and beyond for their employers. In fact, to be viewed as a "medium performer" you have to do things that aren't listed in your job description. CPH continues this tradition of treating nurses poorly. Everything they do just screams, "be thankful you have a job." This seeps down from management, to the nurses. Management truly doesn't keep the patients in mind. I have seen the laziest nurses be given awards. Literally an award given to nurses who lack technical abilities, are lazy, and eat the newer nurses. There a lot of talk about, "these young nurses don't have a good work ethic." The people saying these things constantly leave work to be done, leave meds for the next shift, and don't chart properly. Then they earn an award. Ther is something to be said for being in the nursing profession for 30 years. However, that shouldn't mean that you don't have to do the same amount of work as someone who's been doing it for 10 or fewer years. The allowable level of backbiting is amazing. For example - people have been reprimanded for Posting on Facebook, "Busy night at work. Why doesn't management realize we need more staff!" Mind you these posts were done not during the work shift. What right does management have to do this? When I left they wanted to do an exit interview. It was a total sham because the only question asked was, "Why are you leaving?" It was because I was moving. When I tried to elaborate the person conducting the exit interview said, "thanks that's enough." They didn't listen to me say I was moving because I didn't want to work at CPH any more. The North Country has limited employment opportunities and the thought of being stuck at CPH for life drove me out of the area. In the past 5-6 years all of the good staff has scattered.

review_title: Too many cooks in the kitchen.
pros: I loved the people I worked with day by day. Those that I shared spaces with and actually got to interact with were all great. Pay is pretty good, too. I started out making over $15 per hour. I've been here a year and I am already at $16.25.
cons: It seems like every month a new level of management is being implemented to try to fix problems, but it doesn't help out those actually dealing with the patients. The lead recruiter is incredibly petty and if you have ever wronged her in any way at any point in your life, she with make sure that none of the hiring managers ever see your resume. Your best bet to get in the company is hang out at the bars in Massena, as that is where the recruiter spends all of her time not at work. Befriend her and you are on easy street.  If you want to move up the ranks, you really need to have a friend on the inside. Working hard and hoping management notices is wasted effort. Hiring managers prefer to hire from outside the company, so "getting your foot in the door" doesn't really help. And each manager does things so differently, you need to be careful. One may love your initiative, and the other might prefer you to stay in your lane. Too often we see new people walk in and take a high paying job while there are people just as qualified inside the company already who are ignored.  Hiring managers have no real accountability and don't have to justify their hiring practices to anyone, but seeing it over and over again is just demoralizing. We have temps who are here every day working hard but the permanent positions are going to outsiders who have family and friends in administration. There are unions here, but not for all jobs, and the ones that are there, HR knows how to get around doing things by the rules. If you live in the area and can get in and get benefits, great. But if you are relocating just to work here, you might want to rethink your options.
